abstract.p: This guide is intended for faculty who have adopted a PreTeXt-authored open textbook for their class, particularly for those in the UTMOST study. It includes ideas for integrating common PreTeXt features into teaching practices as well as specific guides

introduction.p: This is a short paragraph to introduce the article (but it is not the abstract). It is optional, in case it would be preferable to have the first section be titled an Introduction.

section.title: Common PreTeXt Features
section.introduction: Not every textbook implements all of this, and not all in an identical way, but this is meant to highlight some basicapabilities for integrating a structured text into the everyday teaching of a class.
section.subsection:
Judicious Linking
The defining feature of hypertext and, perhaps, the web in general is the ability to link from one resource to another. The structure of PreTeXt is ripe for such, both internally, as you regularly see with exercises citing theorems and sections referenceing previous sections, but can also be done externally.
To grab the URL for a Section, simply navigate to the section and copy the URL in your browser's address bar.open the knowl, by clicking the link, then right-click the "In-Context" link at the bottom right and use your browser's "Copy Address Location" feature.

section.title: UTMOST-specific Guide

p.i: This guide is intended for instructors at test-sites participating in the UTMOST project (hence the use of second-person). It may not be relevant to a general audience.

section.p:
Being open source textbooks, there may be several (maybe dozens) of implementations of your textbook on the open web. It is very important you and your students use the AIM-hosted version of the text:
A First Course in Linear Algebra
Abstract AlgebraTheory and Applications
Active Calculus

This paragraph has some inline math, a Diophantine equation, x^2 + \doubler{y^2} = z^2. And some display math about infinite series: \sum_{n=1}^\infty\,\frac{1}{n^2} = \frac{\pi^2}{6}. Look at the XML source to see how macros are employed universally across all possible output formats.
